Hi Nat,
I see that my approach is very similar to yours, and the limited
re=
sponse I've gotten so far is pretty much the same: you better see
how well =
the tests describe the code!

One other interesting effect is that after a =
while I start to get
documentation-driven tests, meaning that I put myself =
in the end users
position, write the documentation for the feature I'm abou=
t to
implement (as a good method name and a comment in the test method),
wr=
ite the test and asserts for it, and then implement the feature.
After havi=
ng run the tests the documentation is ready to be reviewed,
it takes about =
3 secs on my computer (and approx 1 sec is starting up
JRuby).

Right now i=
t is a bit awkward since I write tests for the
documentation features which=
 are mainly comments. I am, however, using
documentation asserts (in the co=
mments) that actually shows up in the
JUnit report in Eclipse, so I get pre=
tty good feedback. One way of
putting it is that I'm test-driving the docum=
entation while I'm
documentation-driving the tests... :-)

I'm still not su=
re exactly the best place to use Bumblebee (or
Protest), but I know that fo=
r API-documentation it will definitely be
a good thing.
With TDDoc I experi=
mented with Abbot tests ("GUI-clicking") where I
complemented the comments =
with images by pulling bitmaps from the
Swing frames, and then generating J=
avaHelp files (using docbook), and
it actually worked (with a few minor fla=
ws). It should be possible to
do the same thing with Bumblebee. I don't wan=
t to start a new thread
on whether GUI-clicking is a good way to test your =
application (I
generally think it is not), but with automatically generated=
 JavaHelp
in the equation the balance might change a bit for some people.

=
Cheers
Daniel, still wanting more feedback

>  On 11/11/2007, Daniel Brolund <dani=
el.brolund@...> wrote:
>  >
>  > Hi all,
>  > I would really apprecia=
te some feedback on a small framework I'm
>  > writing for JUnit 4.4.
>  >
=
>  > I call it Bumblebee, and the purpose of it is to use comments and the
=
>  > structures in the test-suites/cases/methods to create "human-readable"=

>  > documentation. It is especially well suited for writing snippet-heavy=

>  > documentation.
>  >
>  > In short, Bumblebee gets events from the exe=
cution of the tests
>  > (suites/classes/methods) and then parses the class=
es and methods for
>  > specific comments to include.
>  >
>  > By default =
it adds the de-camelcased names of the suites/cases/methods
>  > as heading=
s (a la agile dox), and the contained comments becomes the
>  > paragraphs.=

>  >
>  > The comments are actually handled as Ruby-strings that get execu=
ted in
>  > a Bumblebee execution context before being added to the output.=
 The
>  > execution context is
>  > a kind of DSL for including code-snippe=
ts and other things needed, and
>  > one of the core ideas of Bumblebee is =
that you should be able to
>  > extend that functionality easily.
>  >
>  >=
 More detailed information about Bumblebee can be found at:
>  >
>  > http:=
//www.agical.com/bumblebee/bumblebee_doc.html
>  >
>  > which is of course =
generated with Bumblebee. :-)
>  >
>  > The concept of Bumblebee is the sam=
e as for TDDoc, which me and Joakim
>  > Ohlrogge wrote some time ago as an=
 add-on for RMock. Unfortunately,
>  > TDDoc became a bit of a dead-end tec=
hnically, and Joakim and I thought
>  > it would be a good idea to start fr=
esh. I happened to have the time at
>  > the time and I started it up. So, =
if you like Bumblebee, give half of
>  > your credits to Joakim!
>  >
>  > =
This is an early release, and I will be very happy for any feedback I
>  > =
can get to improve it.
